body.p:
X
Lexington Ky
Oct 29th 1862
Gov Jas. F. Robinson
Dr Sir

The Col of our the 19th Ky Regt. having been assigned the command of the 2d Brigade 1st Div. Army of Ky under Gen A J. Smith. it devolves upon me (its Lt Col) to address you. Suggesting some important wants of the regiment as I conceive them --

Four of our companies are armed with the Springfield & Enfield Rifles. which are of the same calibre & a good gun -- The remaining Six are armed with Belgian muskets. which are of a different calibre from the rifles. This produces great inconvenience in the regiment & the having ammunition of different calibres in an engagement might result in great confusion and serious & inrepairable disaster
Besides the injury from having different calibres the Belgian Musket is an exceedingly inferior weapon. is very heavy & clumsy & with its ammunition makes too great a burden upon the march & won't of all from the inferior construction of its Tube misses fire very often.
I feel that it is almost indespensable to the efficiency of our regiment that its remaining Six col should be armed with Springfield on Enfield rifles.

They have been promised us time & again until we almost feel discouraged at the prospect of getting them & we make this the first appeal to our state authorities for assistance in procuring them. with a feeling that you will do all in your power for us --

We were hurried off mainly a year ago into the service with muskets gathered in from home guards & have managed to gather up the rifles for 4 We need to complete the
matter Springfield on Enfield rifles. I made appreciative & engaging at the ordinances office at Cin as we came through poor encouragement & without the interposition of some of our state authorities I think we will not receive them until the new Free State regts are first Supplied with them to drill & stand guard with --
Ours is the most indifferently armed regt I have ever seen --

Another matter I conceive to be of high importance to the usefulnesss of our regt is that it should be thrown into a field of service sufficienctly remote from the homes of our men to prevent that restlessness to get home & consequent dissatisfaction in camp & frequent desertion which in such situations always render a regt. a source of great trouble & of discredit to its state. We had a great deal of this sort of trouble for 3 or 4 months
& I am exceedingly anxious to avoid it in the future.

These two matters I feel are very worthy of the attention & interposition of our State authorities. Our regt comes from the counties of Mercer. Washington. Boyle Garrard. Lincoln. Pulaski. Perry & Letcher & to avoid the trouble I speak of I would suggestion sending it on the Nashville. on Miss route -- I am aware you have no control in the latter matter but your suggestions to the proper persons might be of great service= We have been cut down in our allowance of tents. one bell tent being isssued to 18 men. (which (should they all be in camp) it is simply a cruelty & outrage to require them to occupy -- -- The act of Congress gives over such tent to 15 men & then they are crowded --

We have about 800 men & 48 tents were isssued to them. but on account of inequality in the size of our companies, there will
be in some cos. a fraction of men over 18. when they are all in without a tent -- the tents having been isssued dividing the whole no of men by 18 -- instead of calculating the wants of each company. To meet the probably wants of our regt. we ought to have aboutat least 15 more tents -- Gen Finnell promised us we should have 22. Mon -- No tin cups plates knives or spoons were isssued to our men. They had to destroy nearly every thing in leaving the gap -- About 500. of each of the above articles would supply our wants --

Them with two coppee mills to each company when first equipped by the State -- If they could be supplied again. they would be of great service to our men. They are generally quite poor men & the State could well afford them small matters to them --
There is nearly Six months pay due us & this should be attended to very speedily -- I know many of our regts have wives & children at home almost destitute --

I hope you will pardon me for setting out such an array of wants -- & proposing so much trouble to you. but I feel I owe it to the men & that they need badly what I have started -- & that we may expect more assistance & sympathy from our own state than elsewhere --
If you have the time to reply & say what you think can be done for us. I will feel greatly obliged to you.
We were not furnished flies for any of our 30 Wall Tents -- & would like very much to ban them
30th Oct -- We are past starting to Camp Dick Robinson Please write me there

19
Lt Col A. J. Cowan
Lexington Ky
Oct 29/62
Cowan John
Lt. Col. 19th Infty (Ky.)
Regtl affairs.
